report_title: Credit Bureaus & Rating Agencies in the US
executive_summary: Credit bureaus and credit rating agents faced much volatility from downstream markets during the current period as COVID-19 and other economic disruptions hung over the US Economy. The diverse nature of downstream clients helped to shield the industry from more significant troubles. Throughout 2020, only a few credit reporters and CRA's downstream clients were greatly affected. Consumers and non-banking businesses took a big hit as unemployment skyrocketed and business closures spiked. Investment from banking institutions and federal and state governments stopped any other falling demand. Downstream demand was further spurred by increasing aggregate household debt as a result of low interest rates and greater financial innovation. High demand from banking institutions and growing household debt also raised profit for credit bureaus

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue has been sustained by growing aggregate household debt
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Much of the industry's revenue comes directly from rating services related to consumer debt. Higher levels of consumer debt are beneficial for companies' core services and heighten the need for more robust credit reporting agencies that can handle a larger quantity of customers. During the current period, consumers had unprecedented access and availability to credit because of low interest rates and financial innovation, leading to boosted demand for consumer credit rating services and benefiting the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Despite the disruptions to the US economy during COVID-19, aggregate household debt still rose in 2020 as the low cost of borrowing spurred home buying. This increased spending on credit reports pertaining to mortgage-backed securities (MBS) and other relevant instruments, helping revenue spike during the pandemic.
BANKING INSTITUTIONS AND GOVERNMENTS HAVE SUPPORTED CRAS AND CREDIT BUREAUS THROUGHOUT THE CURRENT PERIOD
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the US faced a looming recession brought about by COVID-19 disruptions, downstream demand fell across several markets, as exemplified by a sharp plunge in the Consumer Confidence Index in 2020. Early disruptions related to the pandemic caused a major drop in stock prices since investors were very worried about the future. Expansive fiscal and monetary policy and the development of an early vaccine caused investors' confidence to recover a few months later, leading to a massive jump in most stock indices. Banking institutions benefited from the historically strong stock market. Higher equity prices gave finance companies more funds to lend out money. To pursue these investments carefully, they increased their uptake in rating agencies' services, which boosted revenue for the industry. A bolstered government spending agenda gave the industry sustained demand during COVID-19. State, local and the national government financed several large projects and assistance programs. This raised debt levels, keeping the need for debt collectors high as well.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INTEREST RATES AND RECESSIONARY FEARS HAVE FOSTERED GREATER DISRUPTIONS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The US economy experienced high inflation in the years following the pandemic as a result of expansive monetary policy, excessive government spending and supply chain disruptions. To tame inflation, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates significantly in 2022.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Industry Will Benefit From Stable Economic Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As a result of the high cost of borrowing, homebuying plunged since it became more expensive to purchase a new or existing residence. This hindered aggregate household debt and reduced downstream demand for credit bureaus. Rising interest rates also reduced consumer spending and confidence, heightening recessionary fears. These fears caused big declines in stock prices, inhibiting financial institutions' performance and severely curtailing downstream demand from these companies. As a result of these factors, revenue plunged in 2022. As inflation fell and the economy experienced significant economic growth, investors became much more confident and stock prices rose. These developments helped revenue expand in 2023 and 2024.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Despite disruptions related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, the US economy is expected to perform well during the outlook period. Steady GDP growth will encourage business formation, causing more companies to seek loans. Lenders will respond by purchasing rating agencies' and credit bureaus' reports on the creditworthiness of these companies, spurring revenue growth.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While the number of businesses will surge during the outlook period, aggregate household debt will decline. This will be caused by consumers borrowing less money because of fears over uncertain economic events (e.g., recessions), making it more difficult for households to meet their obligations. Lower household debt will hinder the need for credit reports and rating agencies' services, negatively impacting revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CRAS WILL CONTINUE TO REGAIN CREDIBILITY AS TIME PROGRESSES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since the subprime mortgage crisis in the late 2000s, credit-rating agencies have been slowly rebuilding trust and image, emphasizing quality customer service and accelerating the digitization of core credit reporting services. The proliferation of mobile applications and digital data processing among credit rating agencies helped accelerate information breakdown and enabled players to elevate their ability to service customers. Another unique development that will enhance credit bureaus and rating agencies' credibility is the move toward cloud data services, which enable more secure and robust data processing of clients' core information. During the outlook period, agencies will continue to adopt these applications, making them more attractive among potential clients and raising their credibility.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: FOLLOWING MASSIVE GROWTH, THE S&P 500 IS UNLIKELY TO EXPAND AS RAPIDLY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The S&P exhibited historical growth starting in 2019. This is unlikely to continue through 2029 and is poised to expand at a subdued rate through the end of the outlook period, as economic conditions are poised to stabilize. The industry benefitted from massive demand from banks, businesses, consumers and the government after COVID-19, causing stock prices to soar. This set of circumstances is unlikely to happen again, especially in the next five years. Slower growth in the S&P 500 will hinder the amount of excess cash corporations have to lend. This will reduce downstream demand for rating agencies' services from financial institutions, contributing to weakened revenue growth during the outlook period.

industry_definition: This industry comprises companies that provide information, outlooks and ratings on the creditworthiness of particular companies, individuals, securities or financial institutions. The industry can be divided into two primary groups: credit bureaus and credit rating agencies (CRAs). Credit bureaus offer services related to consumer credit information, while CRAs generally focus on businesses, governments, securities and financial markets.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: A strong stock market has sustained revenue growth. This has provided credit rating agencies with a massive downstream market in the form of banking institutions despite COVID-19-related disruptions.

Widespread access to credit supported demand for credit bureaus for most of the current period. Economic uncertainty will reduce access to credit and revenue growth hindered during the outlook period.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The finance sector is responsible for servicing and providing funds for savers, borrowers and investors, which include households, businesses and the government. It includes entities such as banks, credit unions, mortgage brokers and other similar lenders and creditors. Credit reports are used extensively by the finance sector to assess businesses' and individuals' creditworthiness and determine the risks involved. Debt collection services are used by these financial institutions when debtors cannot meet their payment obligations.

Other businesses that use the industry's services include manufacturers, wholesalers, farmers and other service providers. They purchase reports from rating agencies to determine which companies and institutions to lend to. Real estate developers, property managers and landlords often use credit reports to screen tenants and evaluate their ability to pay rent promptly. These businesses use credit bureaus to obtain these reports.

Similar to consumers, retailers use credit bureaus to determine their customers' creditworthiness. Buyers with good credit will often receive discounts to encourage them to flock to their stores more often.

Consumers primarily use credit bureaus to retrieve information about their creditworthiness, such as obtaining credit reports. Since households rarely use rating agencies' services, consumers make up less than one-tenth of revenue.

Other buyers of the industry's services include hospitals, federal, local and state government agencies and non-profit organizations. These groups don't engage in much lending, so they don't need rating agencies' services that often.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Commercial Credit Reports and Rating Services
products_and_services.product_description: Commercial credit reports and rating services comprise the largest revenue share since institutions that seek to lend money to businesses use rating reports frequently to make strategic decisions.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Individual Credit Reports and Rating Services
products_and_services.product_description: Retailers, landlords and credit card companies use individual credit card reports to assess consumers' financial reliability. This enables these businesses to offer individuals with good credit discounts, apartments and great credit cards. These companies often use credit bureaus to access this information.

Other services make up a very small share of revenue, including credit rating services, resale of merchandise and investigation services. Demand for these services isn't particularly high, so their revenue share has remained fairly steady during the current period.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Debt Collection and Risk Management Services
products_and_services.product_description: Purchased debt collection involves the discounted buyout of debt at a negotiated price that businesses cannot collect, saving time and money. This debt acquisition grants collection firms any rights to money collected on a debt portfolio.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for the industry's services is often affected by consumer spending and business loans. When the number of businesses rises, demand from banks and business owners seeking loans increases as well. Similarly, an increase in the number of businesses implies a more favorable business environment, which occurs as unemployment decreases and consumer spending increases. This also typically benefits credit bureaus and rating agencies in the United States.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region accounts for the highest proportion of business locations in the United States, comprising nearly one-quarter of establishments.
The Mid-Atlantic region follows with approximately 18% of establishments and 15% of the population.
The Great Lakes region has around 15% of establishments and 14% of the population.
The Plains region accounts for roughly 10% of establishments and 7% of the population.
The Southwest region has approximately 10% of establishments and 12% of the population.
The Rocky Mountains region has the lowest percentage of both establishments (around 5%) and population (around 5%).
The New England region has around 7% of establishments and 4% of the population.
The West region has approximately 10% of establishments and 13% of the population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This act was created to help foster transparency, accountability and competition in CRAs. This law requires that a CRA looking to be considered a nationally recognized statistical rating organization (NRSRO) must register with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). In doing so, CRAs must make certain information available to the public.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE FAIR CREDIT REPORTING ACT OF 1970
regulations_points.regulation_description: Credit bureaus in the US are regulated by the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA). FCRA governs the reporting of information to CRAs, the proposing of pre-screened credit offers and the sharing of consumer report information. Violation of the FCRA or other state laws is punishable by fines and lawsuits.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE DODD-FRANK WALL STREET REFORM AND CONSUMER PROTECTION ACT OF 2010
regulations_points.regulation_description: Reforming almost every aspect of the financial services industry, Dodd-Frank led to the creation of the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC). In addition to the FSOC, Dodd-Frank established the Consumer Financial Protection Act (2010), which targets banks, card issuers, card network operators and credit bureaus, which came with heavy new regulations and oversight.

barriers_points.barrier_description: CRAs and credit bureaus rely heavily on highly skilled employees well-versed in finance and risk assessment. As a result, labor costs contribute significantly more to barriers to entry than capital.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition depends on the specific segment in this industry. The CRA industry is much less competitive since two major companies dominate it (Standard and Poor's and Moody's).
Increased acquisitions have decreased competition across the industry. Larger companies can expand more and benefit from economies of scale.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Long-standing firms thwart the ability of younger businesses to reduce market concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Larger CRAs benefit from economies of scale
concentration_points.concentration_description: The massive major players commanding an impressive market share can use their size to an advantage. Large CRAs such as Moody's and S&P Global can use economies of scale to offer specific services at a lower per-unit cost. This improves their competitive position compared to smaller firms, raising consolidation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rating agencies demand a high premium for their services
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Financial institutions and other buyers use credit ratings to figure out what kinds of businesses they should lend to. Since this information is extremely valuable for businesses, customers are willing to pay rating agencies a high premium for their services.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The CRA Sector Has Driven Wages Upward
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages represent nearly four-tenths of revenue since financial and risk experts are highly skilled and educated, causing them to demand high compensation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High Rates of Acquisitions and Restructuring Have Kept Other Costs Elevated
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Part of typical operations for larger companies is acquisitions and restructuring. These processes come with large costs. Acquisition activity has remained high, causing other costs to remain one of the largest expenses for credit bureaus and CRAs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: CRAs and credit bureaus rely heavily on highly skilled employees
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: CRAs and credit bureaus rely heavily on highly skilled employees well-versed in finance and risk assessment. As a result, labor costs contribute significantly more to barriers to entry than capital.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Heightened Borrowing During COVID-19 Led to Higher Demand for Services
volatility_points.volatility_description: During the current period, both consumer and corporate borrowing increased. This sustained demand overall for the industry, as many other markets faltered.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Credit Rating Agencies Felt Increased Pressure as the Housing Market Slowed Down in 2022
volatility_points.volatility_description: Credit rating agencies benefit heavily from the insurance of debt instruments such as mortgage-backed securities (MBSs) and collateralized debt obligations (CDOs). As high interest rates caused consumers to pump the breaks on building and buying existing housing in 2022, downstream demand for CRAs dropped, leading to a decline in revenue during the year.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The industry is adding new patent technologies at a rate in line with the average across all industries
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry is adding new patent technologies at a rate in line with the average across all industries, which suggests a stable addition of technology. However, the concentration of technologies is high. This creates the potential for innovation outside the focus of industry leaders to gain traction.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Credit bureaus often offer customers reporting services in addition to monitoring services and identity security services, all under a bundled price.

FAQs.question: Has competition from low-wage countries hurt your business?
FAQs.answer: The types of services the industry offers depend on consumer information in the country they operate in, limiting competition from other nations.

FAQs.question: Does your business have to be located nearby key consumer or client markets?
FAQs.answer: Companies don't need to be geographically close to their clients since most services are based on consumer information, which can be accessed anywhere.

FAQs.question: Does your company rely on hourly or part-time workers?
FAQs.answer: The industry relies almost entirely on full-time, highly skilled employees.

FAQs.question: Does your company use mobile applications to improve client services and consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: Companies that directly interact with consumers tend to have an app to access credit reports and monitor credit ratings.

FAQs.question: Are web-based technologies such as online document storage and video conferencing hurting your business?
FAQs.answer: These platforms are helping rating agencies by expanding the products available to customers.

FAQs.question: Do regulations pertinent to your business vary from state to state?
FAQs.answer: Because of the ubiquitous nature of the industry, regulations are mostly relevant at the federal level, not the state level.

FAQs.question: Is your business responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Companies are supposed to be responsible for the security of personal information.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Companies often buy new software platforms and expanded data storage to account for more customers under their belt.

FAQs.question: Would your company be able to meet its financial obligations in the event of an unforeseen expense?
FAQs.answer: Companies may have to pay massive fines and settlements during recessions if they inaccurately assess the creditworthiness of corporations.

FAQs.question: How have consumers responded to the web-based platforms you offer? How can you improve these platforms?
FAQs.answer: Sales and distribution platforms must be in place to reach consumers. Web-based platforms for client access are required for immediate delivery.

FAQs.question: What security measures are in place for consumers? How have you resolved any issues with security in the past?
FAQs.answer: Consumer protection laws require a high level of security to prevent unauthorized access to databases.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? Does your staff undergo constant training?
FAQs.answer: Credit bureaus and rating agencies need access to analytical and accuracy-oriented staff members.

FAQs.question: How have trends in interest rates affected demand for your products and services?
FAQs.answer: Credit reporting drives rating activity related to consumer and business debt, supporting revenue. The industry also benefits from the issuance of debt securities within capital markets.

FAQs.question: How has rising unemployment affected your business in the past?
FAQs.answer: The unemployment rate is an important indicator of consumer spending and borrowing activity. Consumer spending increases as the unemployment rate falls and per capita disposable income rises.

FAQs.question: How have you managed periods of fluctuating household debt in the past? Are you prepared for the effects of a projected increase in household debt?
FAQs.answer: Much of the industry's revenue comes from rating services related to consumer debt. Credit bureaus benefit from an increase in credit applications associated with credit cards, mortgages or home equity loans. Credit rating agencies profit from repacking and selling consumer loans on the secondary market.
